summary: This document is a forwarded email chain from July 2021, primarily featuring communications from Richard C. Curtiss to various news organizations and government officials. Curtiss attempts to report on alleged corruption within the courts and government, and specifically seeks investigation into the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's death in the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The chain includes responses from news editors declining the story and administrative replies from court and medical examiner offices.

persons.name: Richard C. Curtiss
persons.context: Individual repeatedly emailing news organizations (Thomson Reuters, New York Times) and government officials (US Attorney, Congress members) alleging widespread court corruption and seeking investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. Claims to have been inside the SHU where Epstein died.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Convicted sex offender whose death by hanging (ruled suicide) in the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019, is a central subject of Curtiss's inquiries and allegations of foul play.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned as potentially holding a 'final stash' of blackmail material related to Epstein that could be used for plea negotiations, described as 'so toxic' prosecutors wouldn't touch it.

persons.name: Jim W. Dean
persons.context: News editor who corresponded with Curtiss, initially stating Curtiss's topic was 'too narrow' and 'a local news story,' but later indicated extensive knowledge of Epstein's background.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: US Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Named as the source who sent Curtiss a 'Civilian Crime Report' to fill out and return, per Curtiss's email.

persons.name: Randolph T.
persons.role: Customer Care Advocate, The New York Times
persons.context: New York Times customer service representative responding to Curtiss, directing him to contact the news team for story inquiries.

persons.name: Barbara Sampson
persons.context: Official who ruled Epstein's death a suicide by hanging. Curtiss emails her office requesting Epstein's drug test results from the autopsy.

persons.name: David Schoen
persons.context: Attorney who met with Epstein in jail the day he died to discuss taking over his defense. He is quoted as stating he does not believe Epstein committed suicide.

persons.name: Adam Schiff
persons.context: One of the recipients (along with Pelosi and Nadler) of an email from Curtiss alleging crimes by government employee unions.

persons.name: Nancy Pelosi
persons.context: One of the recipients of an email from Curtiss alleging crimes by government employee unions.

persons.name: Jerrold Nadler
persons.context: One of the recipients of an email from Curtiss alleging crimes by government employee unions.

persons.name: Alexander Vindman
persons.context: Briefly mentioned as the 'original source of Ukraine Investigation,' in a seemingly unrelated snippet of text within the document.

persons.name: James Comey
persons.context: Mentioned in a news snippet regarding his firing, unrelated to the main correspondence.

persons.name: Mike Pence
persons.context: Mentioned in a news snippet regarding comments on Comey's firing, unrelated to the main correspondence.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as potentially holding blackmail material ('final stash') related to Epstein that could be used for plea negotiations.
Schoen met with Epstein in jail the day he died to discuss taking over his defense team.
Curtiss repeatedly emailed Dean, an editor at Thomson Reuters, pitching news stories about court corruption and Epstein's death.
Curtiss received a Civilian Crime Report from US Attorney Strauss to fill out regarding his allegations.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by hanging (ruled a suicide) in the SHU of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City.

events.title: Curtiss Correspondence on Epstein Death
events.description: Richard Curtiss emails editor Jim Dean offering information on why guards turned cameras off and failed to check on Epstein every 30 minutes, claiming he was inside the SHU.

events.title: OCME Confirms Epstein Suicide Ruling
events.description: The NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, via Dr. Barbara Sampson, confirms Epstein's death was ruled a suicide by hanging.

events.title: Editor Declines Corruption Story
events.description: Editor Jim W. Dean responds to Curtiss, stating allegations of court corruption are 'too narrow a topic' and 'a local news story.'

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York City, NY (150 Park Row, New York, NY 10007)
8393 Pardee Hollow Road, Wayland, New York 14572 (Richard Curtiss's address)
Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, 520 1st Avenue, New York, NY 10016
U.S. Court of Appeals Second Circuit, New York, NY
keyFacts: Richard Curtiss, a correspondent, claims to have been inside the Special Housing Unit (SHU) of the Metropolitan Correctional Center where Jeffrey Epstein died and questions the official narrative, citing guards turning off cameras and not performing 30-minute checks.

An email from an editor (Jim Dean) suggests deep, unreported knowledge of Epstein's background and states it was expected Epstein would be 'bumped off' because he had to be 'prevented from talking at all costs.'
Attorney David Schoen, who met with Epstein the day he died to discuss taking over his defense, is quoted as saying he does not believe Epstein committed suicide.
The document includes administrative brush-offs from news organizations and government offices regarding Curtiss's allegations of systemic court corruption and the circumstances of Epstein's death.
Ghislaine Maxwell is characterized as potentially holding a 'final stash' of blackmail material so toxic that prosecutors' employers 'wouldn't touch it with a ten foot pole.'
